importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage by CSIRO scientists in late 2022 led to the discovery of multiple new marine species in the Gascoyne Marine Park, marking a significant milestone in deep-sea exploration.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The deep-sea depth range (122m to over 600m) is where the new species were discovered, highlighting the extreme environments that remain poorly understood and underexplored.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in size, was discovered in the deep waters of the Gascoyne Marine Park, using hairs to catch food instead of claws.
A new species of lantern shark, the West Australian Lantern Shark, was found at depths exceeding 600m, with glowing photophores on its belly and large eyes.
These discoveries underscore Australia's status as a global biodiversity hotspot with over a million unique species, many still unclassified.
The deep-sea exploration in 2022 led to the identification of at least 20 new species, including the Carnavon Flapjack Octopus.
Scientists estimate that around 600 additional species remain to be described and named due to the time-intensive process of verification and classification.
The research was conducted by Australian scientists from CSIRO and the Western Australian Museum, emphasizing collaboration between national science agencies and museums.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country known for its high biodiversity and extensive deep-sea exploration efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia's vast and largely unexplored marine environments are central to the discovery of new species, illustrating its global importance in biological research.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency responsible for conducting deep-sea research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO led the 2022 research voyage in the Gascoyne Marine Park, directly contributing to the discovery of new marine species.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The site of the deep-sea research voyage where the new species were discovered, highlighting the ecological significance of protected marine zones.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly described deep-sea shark species with bioluminescent features and large eyes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species is one of the key discoveries from the expedition, demonstrating the unique adaptations of deep-sea organisms to extreme environments.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of crab that feeds using modified mouthparts with long hairs rather than claws.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The discovery of a new, small porcelain crab species reveals unique feeding behaviors and adaptations in deep-sea crustaceans.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly identified small octopus species, approximately 4cm in size and rusty red in color.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species is part of a broader group of new discoveries, showcasing the diversity of invertebrate life in unexplored deep-sea regions.

namedEntities.name: Western Australian Museum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A museum that houses aquatic zoology collections and supports marine research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The museum's Dr. Andrew Hosie provided expert insight into the porcelain crab's feeding mechanism, emphasizing academic collaboration.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist from CSIRO who contributed to the study of lantern sharks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr. White explained the bioluminescent characteristics of lantern sharks, which are key to understanding their survival in deep-sea environments.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A curator of aquatic zoology from the Western Australian Museum.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr. Hosie provided scientific explanation regarding the feeding behavior of the porcelain crab, adding depth to the biological understanding of the species.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO and the Western Australian Museum discovered two new species in the deep sea off Western Australia during a 2022 research voyage in the Gascoyne Marine Park: a tiny, semi-transparent porcelain crab (1.5cm long) feeding with hairs and a glowing West Australian Lantern Shark (up to 40cm) found at depths over 600m. These discoveries highlight Australiaâ€™s status as a global biodiversity hotspot, with over a million species, many still unexplored. Out of the hundreds of specimens collected, 20 new species have been identified, with scientists estimating that around 600 more remain to be described and named due to the lengthy process of classification and verification.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
